#Text=CHAPTER XIII .
#Text=A FOREST PAGE

#Text=When the survivors of the band of Wyoming fugitives that the five had helped were behind the walls of Fort Penn , securing the food and rest they needed so greatly , Henry Ware and his comrades felt themselves relieved of a great responsibility .
#Text=They were also aware how much they owed to Timmendiquas , because few of the Indians and renegades would have been so forbearing .
#Text=Thayendanegea seemed to them inferior to the great Wyandot .
#Text=Often when Brant could prevent the torture of the prisoners and the slaughter of women and children , he did not do it .
#Text=The five could never forget these things in after life , when Brant was glorified as a great warrior and leader .
#Text=Their minds always turned to Timmendiquas as the highest and finest of Indian types .
#Text=While they were at Fort Penn two other parties came , in a fearful state of exhaustion , and also having paid the usual toll of death on the way .
#Text=Other groups reached the Moravian towns , where they were received with all kindness by the German settlers .
#Text=The five were able to give some help to several of these parties , but the beautiful Wyoming Valley lay utterly in ruins .
#Text=The ruthless fury of the savages and of many of the Tories , Canadians , and Englishmen , can scarcely be told .
#Text=Everything was slaughtered or burned .
#Text=As a habitation of human beings or of anything pertaining to human beings , the valley for a time ceased to be .

#Text=An entire population was either annihilated or driven out , and finally Butler 's army , finding that nothing more was left to be destroyed , gathered in its war parties and marched northward with a vast store of spoils , in which scalps were conspicuous .
#Text=When they repassed Tioga Point , Timmendiquas and his Wyandots were still with them .
#Text=Thayendanegea was also with them here , and so was Walter Butler , who was destined shortly to make a reputation equaling that of his father , “ Indian ” Butler .
#Text=Nor had the terrible Queen Esther ever left them .
#Text=She marched at the head of the army , singing , horrid chants of victory , and swinging the great war tomahawk , which did not often leave her hand .
#Text=The whole force was re-embarked upon the Susquehanna , and it was still full of the impulse of savage triumph .
#Text=Wild Indian songs floated along the stream or through the meadows , which were quiet now .
#Text=They advanced at their ease , knowing that there was nobody to attack them , but they were watched by five woodsmen , two of whom were boys .

#Text=Meanwhile the story of Wyoming , to an extent that neither Indians nor woodsmen themselves suspected , was spreading from town to town in the East , to invade thence the whole civilized world , and to stir up an indignation and horror that would make the name Wyoming long memorable .
#Text=Wyoming had been a victory for the flag under which the invaders fought , but it sadly tarnished the cause of that flag , and the consequences were to be seen soon .

#Text=Henry Ware , Paul Cotter , Sol Hyde , Tom Ross , and Jim Hart were thinking little of distant consequences , but they were eager for the present punishment of these men who had committed so much cruelty .
#Text=From the bushes they could easily follow the canoes , and could recognize some of their occupants .
#Text=In one of the rear boats sat Braxton Wyatt and a young man whom they knew to be Walter Butler , a pallid young man , animated by the most savage ferocity against the patriots .
#Text=He and Wyatt seemed to be on the best of terms , and faint echoes of their laughter came to the five who were watching among the bushes on the river bank .
#Text=Certainly Braxton Wyatt and he were a pair well met .
#Text=“ Henry , ” said Shif'less Sol longingly , “ I think I could jest about reach Braxton Wyatt with a bullet from here .
#Text=I ai n't over fond o ' shootin ' from ambush , but I done got over all scruples so fur ez he 's concerned .
#Text=Jest one bullet , one little bullet , Henry , an ' ef I miss I wo n't ask fur a second chance . ”
#Text=“ No , Sol , it wo n't do , ” said Henry .
#Text=“ They 'd get off to hunt us .
#Text=The whole fleet would be stopped , and we want ' em to go on as fast as possible . ”
#Text=“ I s'pose you 're right , Henry , ” said the shiftless one sadly , “ but I 'd jest like to try it once .
#Text=I 'd give a month 's good huntin ' for that single trial . ”
#Text=After watching the British-Indian fleet passing up the river , they turned back to the site of the Wyoming fort and the houses near it .
#Text=Here everything had been destroyed .
#Text=It was about dusk when they approached the battlefield , and they heard a dreadful howling , chiefly that of wolves .
#Text=“ I think we 'd better turn away , ” said Henry .
#Text=“ We could n't do anything with so many . ”
#Text=They agreed with him , and , going back , followed the Indians up the Susquehanna .
#Text=A light rain fell that night , but they slept under a little shed , once attached to a house which had been destroyed by fire .
#Text=In some way the shed had escaped the flames , and it now came into timely use .

#Text=The five , cunning in forest practice , drew up brush on the sides , and half-burned timber also , and , spreading their blankets on ashes which had not long been cold , lay well sheltered from the drizzling rain , although they did not sleep for a long time .
